article.title: Detection of Genes in Arabidopsis thaliana L. Responding to DNA Damage from Radiation and Other Stressors in Spaceflight
article.abstract: Ionizing radiation present in extraterrestrial environment is an important factor that affects plants grown in spaceflight.

sections.introduction: Space is an environment that may have harmful effects on living organisms due to its hostile characteristics such as low oxygen, microgravity, lower pressure, and radiation.
sections.methods: Datasets from the GeneLab repository [20] are mined for studying the effects of low radiation doses in low Earth orbit, and very high doses of high LET and gamma photos found beyond Earthâ€™s atmosphere on Arabidopsis.
sections.results: The gene expression values (three in GLDS-120, three in GLDS-38, five in GLDS -7, six in GLDS-37, and eight in GLDS-46) are used to construct Pearson correlation GRNs.
sections.discussion: Radiation data for GLDS studies in the ISS are provided in [52].

experimental_factors.treatment: low radiation doses, very high doses of high let, gamma photos
experimental_factors.treatment_raw: low radiation doses, very high doses of high LET and gamma photos
treatment_list: very high doses of high let

treatment_detail.text: very high doses of high LET
treatment_detail.normalized: very high doses of high let

experimental_factors.duration_raw: about six weeks from germination to mature plants

duration_detail.raw: about six weeks from germination to mature plants

article.insights_summary: Ionizing radiation present in extraterrestrial environment is an important factor that affects plants grown in spaceflight. The gene expression values are used to construct Pearson correlation GRNs.
article.acknowledgments: The material contained in this document is based upon work supported by National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) grant 80NSSC19M0167.
